claim: Although malicious actors will misuse AI, the net societal impact is likely to be positive worldwide: most people will employ AI to learn, innovate, and achieve advances (including medical breakthroughs), and its limitations will ultimately push humans to focus more on distinctively human pursuits such as caregiving, teamwork, deep reading, creative exploration, and spiritual growth.
explanation: Parts of the claim are plausible—AI has already enabled scientific advances such as DeepMind’s AlphaFold‑3 for biomolecular interactions and AI‑designed drugs reaching Phase II trials—but the broader prediction remains speculative. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC11168924/?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [europeanpharmaceuticalreview.com](https://www.europeanpharmaceuticalreview.com/news/184106/first-ai-generated-small-molecule-drug-enters-phase-ii-trial/?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) Leading analyses find both potential productivity gains and significant risks (job disruption and rising inequality), so a net positive worldwide impact is uncertain, not established. ([imf.org](https://www.imf.org/en/Blogs/Articles/2024/01/14/ai-will-transform-the-global-economy-lets-make-sure-it-benefits-humanity?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [oecd.org](https://www.oecd.org/en/publications/oecd-employment-outlook-2023_08785bba-en/full-report/artificial-intelligence-job-quality-and-inclusiveness_a713d0ad.html?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) Current adoption and sentiment also do not show that most people are using AI primarily to learn and innovate. ([pewresearch.org](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2025/06/25/34-of-us-adults-have-used-chatgpt-about-double-the-share-in-2023/?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) Security agencies report growing criminal misuse, underscoring the mixed societal effects. ([apnews.com](https://apnews.com/article/846847536f6feb2bbb423943fd96e1f1?utm_source=chatgpt.com))
